narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: I was able to go to my research lab in person this semester.
This is a student-led research for credit class, which for me took the form of both in-person experimentation (following Yale Med School + research guidelines) and remote data analysis.
This wasn't a class that met, so in conducting my research, I would meet with my mentor and PI over Zoom.
Independent (remote) work and Zoom meetings with PI and lab members
In -person lab experience learning to operate TEM.
Independent remote research

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Mostly what I learned this semester was from interacting with my PI/postdoc mentor directly in lab rather than through this course.

I learned how to write a rigorous scientific research paper, from the background to formulating experiments, to quantifying, analyzing, and making sense of the data. This semester, most of what I learned was soft skills including experimental design, patience, and how to draw connections between different data.

I learned how to write project proposals for the natural sciences, along with how to write a corresponding report past a certain stage in the research. With my mentor, I learned more about how to conduct research in our field independently.
I learned how to do a literature search, how to analyze PyMol structures, and how to present results in a coherent narrative.
I gained the ability to analyze cryoET data and learn sub-tomogram averaging.
I gained valuable research experience, as well as skills in planning and writing a paper in scientific research format.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I am rating my engagement with this course very low because I really did not think about this class except the beginning/end of the semester. The primary point of this class is to go to your lab 10+ hours/week and perform research there. I think that there should have been more communication between the course coordinators and students' PIs, as I had to provide my PI with basically all of the information on grading and supervision from this course and they were often confused as to what was expected of them as a supervisor with regard to grading. 
I also never received feedback on my proposal from the coordinator, which made me confused as to who was actually grading me and how.

This course gives lots of freedom and pretty much everything is dependent on your PI/postdoc. The course itself is what you would expect. The only required components are a research proposal, research presentation (at a lab meeting), and a final paper. My only critique is that I never got a grade or comments back on my research proposal, which would have been very helpful in writing my final paper.

Strength: was very nice to have leeway to do the work without an excess of extraneous work. Weakness: the structure is currently a bit lacking. Due dates, rubrics, syllabus need to be there/updated for clarity. Given how it is also a course that does not currently engage students beyond the mentor relationship, assignments should really be posted at the beginning of the semester. Also it does not really make sense to have to email any assignments when the Canvas tool exists.

Strengths: lots of flexibility to do independent research, opportunity for mentorship from PI
Weaknesses: hard to stay engaged, especially this semester with everything being remote
This course was an independent research course and thus very flexible. I enjoyed working remotely in lab and learned about cryoET data collection, processing, and analysis.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I don't think this class would have functioned any different in a non-COVID world. I was still able to perform in-person research and submitted all my assignments through Canvas.
Again, everything was entirely up to the PI/postdoc.
N/A

Success: flexibility
Weaknesses: several "checkpoints" throughout the semester would have helped me to stay more engaged
The engagement level was very high for me, I hope to continue my research project with Prof. Hong Zhou.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I think I gave this course some poor ratings but it's really not that bad. If you like performing research and have no trouble contributing 10 (but really more like 15) hours per week to your research lab, you may as well take this class and get credit for it. The only assignments are a short proposal due in September, and then a final report in December. The report can take a little long, but it's good to reflect on what you accomplished over the semester.
You really have to like research and your lab mentors.
Yes! I think it is a great opportunity to further your time doing research in a lab whilst building skills that will prove useful in research and beyond.
Yes, good opportunity to get immersed into a lab.
Yes, this was a phenomenal course designed for independent research in the major.
